channel.title: Kinase on RD's Blog
channel.description: Recent content in Kinase on RD's Blog

item.title: Anchor Residues in Protein–Protein Interactions
item.description: Notes on 2004 PNAS paper introducing the concept of anchor residues as key pre-configured side chains that drive protein–protein interactions. The study highlights a two-step binding mechanism, combining preformed ‘anchor’ interactions and induced-fit adjustments.

item.title: Anchor Residues in Protein–Protein Interactions
item.description: Notes on 2004 PNAS paper introducing the concept of anchor residues as key pre-configured side chains that drive protein–protein interactions. The study highlights a two-step binding mechanism, combining preformed ‘anchor’ interactions and induced-fit adjustments.

item.title: Identification of a Major Determinant for Serine-Threonine Kinase Phosphoacceptor Specificity
item.description: Notes on 2014 Cell paper that identifies the ‘DFG+1’ residue as a key determinant of Ser/Thr kinase phosphoacceptor specificity, with structural and biochemical validation.

item.title: Identification of a Major Determinant for Serine-Threonine Kinase Phosphoacceptor Specificity
item.description: Notes on 2014 Cell paper that identifies the ‘DFG+1’ residue as a key determinant of Ser/Thr kinase phosphoacceptor specificity, with structural and biochemical validation.

item.title: The Hallmark of AGC Kinase Functional Divergence is Its C-terminal Tail, a Cis-acting Regulatory Module
item.description: An elegant dissection of how the C-terminal tail (C-tail) in AGC kinases serves as a cis-acting regulatory module, driving functional divergence from other kinase families. Through conserved interactions and structural specialization, the C-tail orchestrates key regulatory processes, acting as a unique hallmark of AGC kinases.

item.title: The Hallmark of AGC Kinase Functional Divergence is Its C-terminal Tail, a Cis-acting Regulatory Module
item.description: An elegant dissection of how the C-terminal tail (C-tail) in AGC kinases serves as a cis-acting regulatory module, driving functional divergence from other kinase families. Through conserved interactions and structural specialization, the C-tail orchestrates key regulatory processes, acting as a unique hallmark of AGC kinases.

item.title: An Inherent Difference Between Serine and Threonine Phosphorylation: Phosphothreonine Strongly Prefers a Highly Ordered, Compact, Cyclic Conformation
item.description: Notes on 2023 ACS paper exploring structural differences between serine and threonine phosphorylation, focusing on phosphothreonine’s preference for ordered conformations.

item.title: An Inherent Difference Between Serine and Threonine Phosphorylation: Phosphothreonine Strongly Prefers a Highly Ordered, Compact, Cyclic Conformation
item.description: Notes on 2023 ACS paper exploring structural differences between serine and threonine phosphorylation, focusing on phosphothreonine’s preference for ordered conformations.

item.title: Molecular Mechanism Underlying Ca²⁺/Calmodulin Dependent Protein Kinase Kinase (CaMKK) Signal Transduction
item.description: An in-depth review of CaMKK signaling, including structural, regulatory, and functional insights into its activation, downstream effects, and implications for disease.

item.title: Molecular Mechanism Underlying Ca²⁺/Calmodulin Dependent Protein Kinase Kinase (CaMKK) Signal Transduction
item.description: An in-depth review of CaMKK signaling, including structural, regulatory, and functional insights into its activation, downstream effects, and implications for disease.

item.title: DFGmodel: Predicting Protein Kinase Structure in Inactive States for Structure-based Discovery of Type-II Inhibitors
item.description: Notes on 2014 ACS paper introducing DFGmodel, a computational approach to predict kinase inactive structures for type-II inhibitor discovery. Includes insights on DFG-flip and kinase conformational analysis.

item.title: DFGmodel: Predicting Protein Kinase Structure in Inactive States for Structure-based Discovery of Type-II Inhibitors
item.description: Notes on 2014 ACS paper introducing DFGmodel, a computational approach to predict kinase inactive structures for type-II inhibitor discovery. Includes insights on DFG-flip and kinase conformational analysis.

item.title: Regulation of Protein Kinases: Activation Segment Conformation and Functional Control
item.description: Notes on 2004 Molecular Cell review analyzing how activation segment conformation regulates protein kinase activity, including insights into RD pocket, anchor residues, and alternative activation mechanisms.

item.title: Regulation of Protein Kinases: Activation Segment Conformation and Functional Control
item.description: Notes on 2004 Molecular Cell review analyzing how activation segment conformation regulates protein kinase activity, including insights into RD pocket, anchor residues, and alternative activation mechanisms.

item.title: Surface Comparison Reveals Conserved Activation Mechanism in Protein Kinases
item.description: Notes on 2006_PNAS paper exploring conserved structural mechanisms of kinase activation via surface comparison.

item.title: Community Analysis of PKA: A Dynamic View of Kinase Architecture
item.description: Notes on a 2014 PNAS paper analyzing PKA dynamics through community analysis.

item.title: Protein Kinases: Evolution of Dynamic Regulatory Proteins
item.description: Notes on 2010 Cell Review article exploring the structural and evolutionary principles that shape the dynamic regulatory mechanisms of protein kinases.

item.title: Protein Kinases: Evolution of Dynamic Regulatory Proteins
item.description: Notes on 2010 Cell Review article exploring the structural and evolutionary principles that shape the dynamic regulatory mechanisms of protein kinases.

item.title: The Conformational Plasticity of Protein Kinases
item.description: Notes on 2002 Cell review discussing conformational plasticity of protein kinases, highlighting key structural elements, activation mechanisms, and pseudosubstrate regulation. Includes insights on αC helix, activation loop, and therapeutic implications (e.g., Gleevec binding).

item.title: The Conformational Plasticity of Protein Kinases
item.description: Notes on 2002 Cell review discussing conformational plasticity of protein kinases, highlighting key structural elements, activation mechanisms, and pseudosubstrate regulation. Includes insights on αC helix, activation loop, and therapeutic implications (e.g., Gleevec binding).

item.title: F-Helix as a Structural Scaffold for Active Protein Kinase Assembly
item.description: Notes on 2008_PNAS paper revealing F-helix as a hub for regulatory and catalytic spine anchoring in protein kinases.

item.title: F-Helix as a Structural Scaffold for Active Protein Kinase Assembly
item.description: Notes on 2008_PNAS paper revealing F-helix as a hub for regulatory and catalytic spine anchoring in protein kinases.

item.title: CASK Functions as a Mg²⁺-Independent Neurexin Kinase
item.description: The study redefines CASK as an active Mg²⁺-independent kinase that phosphorylates neurexin, integrating scaffolding and enzymatic functions, challenging its previous classification as a pseudokinase.

item.title: CASK Functions as a Mg²⁺-Independent Neurexin Kinase
item.description: The study redefines CASK as an active Mg²⁺-independent kinase that phosphorylates neurexin, integrating scaffolding and enzymatic functions, challenging its previous classification as a pseudokinase.

item.title: Homing In: Mechanisms of Substrate Targeting by Protein Kinases
item.description: Notes on the 2018 Trends in Biochemical Sciences review covering diverse mechanisms by which protein kinases achieve substrate specificity. The paper explores recognition motifs, docking interactions, adaptor-mediated recruitment, and multisite phosphorylation, highlighting how these shape signaling networks. (Still can’t like this paper — 23.03.23)

item.title: Homing In: Mechanisms of Substrate Targeting by Protein Kinases
item.description: Notes on the 2018 Trends in Biochemical Sciences review covering diverse mechanisms by which protein kinases achieve substrate specificity. The paper explores recognition motifs, docking interactions, adaptor-mediated recruitment, and multisite phosphorylation, highlighting how these shape signaling networks. (Still can’t like this paper — 23.03.23)

item.title: Autophosphorylation: A Salient Feature of Protein Kinases
item.description: Notes on the fundamental roles and mechanisms of protein kinase autophosphorylation, including examples from PKA, PKC, MLCK, RTKs, and others. Functional effects and evolutionary perspectives are also discussed.

item.title: Autophosphorylation: A Salient Feature of Protein Kinases
item.description: Notes on the fundamental roles and mechanisms of protein kinase autophosphorylation, including examples from PKA, PKC, MLCK, RTKs, and others. Functional effects and evolutionary perspectives are also discussed.

item.title: Assembly of Allosteric Macromolecular Switches: Lessons from PKA
item.description: Comprehensive review on how PKA holoenzyme assembly provides unique insights into kinase regulation, highlighting regulatory-catalytic subunit interactions, anchoring proteins, and macromolecular scaffolds.

item.title: Assembly of Allosteric Macromolecular Switches: Lessons from PKA
item.description: Comprehensive review on how PKA holoenzyme assembly provides unique insights into kinase regulation, highlighting regulatory-catalytic subunit interactions, anchoring proteins, and macromolecular scaffolds.

item.title: Ile441 Is Essential for Autoinhibition of CaMKK: Regulatory Mechanism of Ca2+/Calmodulin-Dependent Protein Kinase Kinase
item.description: Notes on a 2000 JBC paper dissecting the autoinhibitory mechanism of CaMKK, identifying Ile441 as critical for maintaining the inactive state, and showing that CaM-binding peptide orientation does not dictate relief from autoinhibition — a pivotal insight into CaMKK regulation.

item.title: Ile441 Is Essential for Autoinhibition of CaMKK: Regulatory Mechanism of Ca2+/Calmodulin-Dependent Protein Kinase Kinase
item.description: Notes on a 2000 JBC paper dissecting the autoinhibitory mechanism of CaMKK, identifying Ile441 as critical for maintaining the inactive state, and showing that CaM-binding peptide orientation does not dictate relief from autoinhibition — a pivotal insight into CaMKK regulation.

item.title: Mechanism of CDK Activation Revealed by the Structure of a CyclinA-CDK2 Complex
item.description: Notes on a 1995 Nature paper revealing the structural mechanism of CDK2 activation by cyclinA, focusing on key conformational changes that relieve autoinhibition and organize the catalytic site.

item.title: Mechanism of CDK Activation Revealed by the Structure of a CyclinA-CDK2 Complex
item.description: Notes on a 1995 Nature paper revealing the structural mechanism of CDK2 activation by cyclinA, focusing on key conformational changes that relieve autoinhibition and organize the catalytic site.

item.title: How Do Kinases Transfer Phosphoryl Groups
item.description: Notes on 1998 Cell review discussing kinase phosphoryl transfer mechanisms, conformational dynamics, cofactor roles, and binding motifs. Highlights the debate between associative (SN2) and dissociative (SN1) pathways, with structural evidence for both models.

item.title: How Do Kinases Transfer Phosphoryl Groups
item.description: Notes on 1998 Cell review discussing kinase phosphoryl transfer mechanisms, conformational dynamics, cofactor roles, and binding motifs. Highlights the debate between associative (SN2) and dissociative (SN1) pathways, with structural evidence for both models.

item.title: Regulation of the ABC Kinases by Phosphorylation: Protein Kinase C as a Paradigm
item.description: A landmark review on the ordered, site-specific phosphorylation events governing the maturation, activation, and regulation of ABC kinases — using PKC as a paradigm — with profound insights into kinase life cycles, structural stabilization, and multi-step control mechanisms.

item.title: Regulation of the ABC Kinases by Phosphorylation: Protein Kinase C as a Paradigm
item.description: A landmark review on the ordered, site-specific phosphorylation events governing the maturation, activation, and regulation of ABC kinases — using PKC as a paradigm — with profound insights into kinase life cycles, structural stabilization, and multi-step control mechanisms.

item.title: Unique Conformational Adaptation of Calmodulin to CaMKK: A Distinct Mode of Calcium-Dependent Kinase Regulation
item.description: Notes on a landmark Nature (1999) paper detailing how calmodulin (CaM) adopts a unique binding mode when interacting with CaMKK, revealing an extended 26-residue peptide interface and an opposite binding orientation, distinguishing it from classical CaM-target interactions — a new paradigm in calcium signaling complexes.

item.title: Unique Conformational Adaptation of Calmodulin to CaMKK: A Distinct Mode of Calcium-Dependent Kinase Regulation
item.description: Notes on a landmark Nature (1999) paper detailing how calmodulin (CaM) adopts a unique binding mode when interacting with CaMKK, revealing an extended 26-residue peptide interface and an opposite binding orientation, distinguishing it from classical CaM-target interactions — a new paradigm in calcium signaling complexes.

item.title: Autonomous Activity of CaMKKβ via Intramolecular Autophosphorylation at Thr482: A Mechanism to Bypass Calcium-Calmodulin Dependency
item.description: Notes on a 2011 ACS Biochemistry study showing that CaMKKβ, unlike CaMKKα, achieves high autonomous activity via intramolecular autophosphorylation at Thr482, partially releasing itself from autoinhibition and making it Ca2+/CaM-independent — revealing a unique kinase regulation mechanism within the CaMKK family.

item.title: Autonomous Activity of CaMKKβ via Intramolecular Autophosphorylation at Thr482: A Mechanism to Bypass Calcium-Calmodulin Dependency
item.description: Notes on a 2011 ACS Biochemistry study showing that CaMKKβ, unlike CaMKKα, achieves high autonomous activity via intramolecular autophosphorylation at Thr482, partially releasing itself from autoinhibition and making it Ca2+/CaM-independent — revealing a unique kinase regulation mechanism within the CaMKK family.

item.title: Common Activation Mechanism in CDPK: Structural Insights into CAD Refolding
item.description: Note on the detailed structural study of CDPK activation, focusing on apicomplexan CAD conformations (CpCDPK, PfCDPK3), offering new insight into a potentially universal activation mechanism for CDPKs.

item.title: Common Activation Mechanism in CDPK: Structural Insights into CAD Refolding
item.description: Note on the detailed structural study of CDPK activation, focusing on apicomplexan CAD conformations (CpCDPK, PfCDPK3), offering new insight into a potentially universal activation mechanism for CDPKs.

item.title: N-terminal Domain of CDPK1 Determines Substrate Specificity: A Key to Rewiring Kinase Signaling
item.description: Note on the discovery that the variable N-terminal domain of CDPK1 controls substrate specificity—offering a new mechanism to engineer signaling specificity in plants.

item.title: N-terminal Domain of CDPK1 Determines Substrate Specificity: A Key to Rewiring Kinase Signaling
item.description: Note on the discovery that the variable N-terminal domain of CDPK1 controls substrate specificity—offering a new mechanism to engineer signaling specificity in plants.

item.title: Structure of the Regulatory Apparatus of a Calcium-Dependent Protein Kinase (CDPK): A Novel Mode of Calmodulin-Target Recognition
item.description: A 2006 JMB study presenting the crystal structure of Arabidopsis CDPK’s regulatory domain, revealing a domain-swapped dimer and an unexpected mechanism of calmodulin-like domain (CaM-LD) recognition, challenging classical calmodulin-target models.

item.title: Structure of the Regulatory Apparatus of a Calcium-Dependent Protein Kinase (CDPK): A Novel Mode of Calmodulin-Target Recognition
item.description: A 2006 JMB study presenting the crystal structure of Arabidopsis CDPK’s regulatory domain, revealing a domain-swapped dimer and an unexpected mechanism of calmodulin-like domain (CaM-LD) recognition, challenging classical calmodulin-target models.

item.title: KALRN: A Central Regulator of Synaptic Function and Synaptopathies (Gene, 2021)
item.description: Comprehensive review of kalirin (KALRN) as a regulator of synaptic plasticity, its molecular domains and isoforms, and its emerging link to neurodevelopmental and neuropsychiatric disorders.

item.title: KALRN: A Central Regulator of Synaptic Function and Synaptopathies (Gene, 2021)
item.description: Comprehensive review of kalirin (KALRN) as a regulator of synaptic plasticity, its molecular domains and isoforms, and its emerging link to neurodevelopmental and neuropsychiatric disorders.

item.title: A Critical Evolution of Protein Kinase Regulation by Activation Loop Autophosphorylation
item.description: Notes on the 2023 eLife review analyzing protein kinase activation loop autophosphorylation. Discusses cis vs. trans mechanisms, dimerization, regulation, and the biochemical, structural, and kinetic evidence for these processes, while addressing the enigmatic nature of autophosphorylation.

item.title: A Critical Evolution of Protein Kinase Regulation by Activation Loop Autophosphorylation
item.description: Notes on the 2023 eLife review analyzing protein kinase activation loop autophosphorylation. Discusses cis vs. trans mechanisms, dimerization, regulation, and the biochemical, structural, and kinetic evidence for these processes, while addressing the enigmatic nature of autophosphorylation.

item.title: Kinetic and Catalytic Mechanisms of Protein Kinases
item.description: Comprehensive notes on the 2001 Chemical Reviews paper exploring the catalytic and kinetic mechanisms of protein kinases, with PKA as a model system. Covers substrate recognition, metal ion roles, phosphoryl transfer mechanisms, activation loop function, and rate-determining steps.

item.title: Kinetic and Catalytic Mechanisms of Protein Kinases
item.description: Comprehensive notes on the 2001 Chemical Reviews paper exploring the catalytic and kinetic mechanisms of protein kinases, with PKA as a model system. Covers substrate recognition, metal ion roles, phosphoryl transfer mechanisms, activation loop function, and rate-determining steps.
